replies.author: @ryanlazarus3381
replies.text:
Read Gabriel Kolko‚Äôs, ‚ÄúTriumph of Conservatism‚Äù and Murray Rothbard‚Äôs, ‚ÄúThe Progressive Era‚Äù. 

Kolko was a socialist but he came to basically the same conclusion as Rothbard who was an anarcho-capitalist. Monopolies are incredibly difficult to build and basically impossible to maintain without the government enforcing the monopoly. The same goes for cartels. So long as competition isn‚Äôt banned or heavily restricted by the government, competition will kill the monopoly or the monopoly will kill itself through mismanagement because large firms are extremely difficult to run. 

The ‚Äúmonopolies‚Äù that were achieved, like Standard Oil, were quickly challenged by competitors and before Standard Oil was broken up, it had already lost a massive chunk of its market share. 

Google has a ‚Äúmonopoly‚Äù on search but it still has substantial competitors. 

There‚Äôs no reason to believe that free markets will create abusive monopolies that last for any significant amount of time. 

In the case of infrastructure where a monopoly is either necessary or desirable, that infrastructure can be owned cooperatively so that there isn‚Äôt someone who can abuse that monopoly status. That means the roads, electrical grid, sewer, etc.

author: @whynautchase
text:
I can tell Aleks was begging for a semantic argument against "voluntaryism" or whatever, so while I think Eddie's points are better and more important, I will offer a possible argument on the level that Aleks was looking for.

First of all, I was super annoyed that he just kept repeating "work or die dichotomy" over and over again; that's not really a dichotomy, it's more of a dilemma. A dichotomy is a relation between contrasting concepts, like "work and leisure" or "life and death" are dichotomies, not two alternative choices in a dilemma like "work or die." Using big words didn't really work out for you here. Also, to really emphasize the dilemma aspect, it would be more accurate to say "die or be exploited," as under capitalism, even your utopian capitalism(1), labor will always be exploited.

Second, I would disagree with your definition that an action must be forced /by another person/ in order for it to be involuntary. Isn't it just the case that it is the pain of hunger that /forces/ me to eat, or the pain of cold that /forces/ me to find shelter, or the fear of death that /forces/ me to keep myself alive. If I was invulnerable I wouldn't bother with any of these things, so they are /involuntary./ Isn't it obvious that death is always involuntary? (ignoring certain cases of suicide.) No one would ever die if the alternative was possible or better, hence if anyone dies, they didn't really have any other option, so it was involuntary, and so your definition is too arbitrary and restrictive to cover the real applications of the concept. Furthermore, I would never willingly allow my labor to be exploited, so the "work" option, under capitalism, is also involuntary. Hence the nature of a dilemma: the choice between two involuntary options.

Which leads me to reformulate a point that Eddie made, isn't it the case that being in the position of the dilemma is itself involuntary? Eddie points out the third option: fight for a better condition for the working class. E.g., rather than a condition of "die or be exploited" any worker would prefer a condition of "perform a small amount of necessary labor relative to the amount under capitalism, and use the new remaining free time for leisure or voluntary labor." However, the body /always/ preventing that from happening is the state. So, both options under capitalism are involuntary, and the enforcer is the state. There is no capitalism without a state, as Eddie pointed out, because workers would revolt and create socialism. Is that not a perfectly valid defeater of your argument?

(1) Market anarchy, just like regular anarchy, is inherently unstable (c.f. Hobbes for some of the early arguments about this), and so even if ancap was miraculously achieved as you say, it would soon give way to state-like entities, i.e. monopolies and capitalist oligarchies, whose interest is to extract as much profit from their workers as possible, i.e. as Marx clearly lays out, exploit and oppress them. So not only is your voluntaryist ethical framework rather arbitrary and immature, your libertarian utopia is less ethical than socialism because it inevitably gives way to a what you call crony capitalism, whereas socialism seeks a condition that is both stable and ethical.

@HardenedH3ro it's not a question of work itself, but what system of work you live in. Saying "humans have always needed to work to survive, so ANY situation in which you work to survive must be a good system" is not a good take. 

Also, to say that anyone who questions the efficiency of that system must be a lazy sucker who wants to mooch off everyone else, is also dumb imo. In fact, that's the origin of most leftist ideology. The main criticism of capitalism is the fact that most of the resources get directed to a select few who found themselves with the ability to buy capital.  Simply buy having resources, you can purchase the mechanisms humanity needs to survive, and fill your pockets. There's also landlords etc. You wanna talk about leeches of the system, you're in the right system. People always try to paint leftism as "I just don't wanna work" but it's more about questioning the efficiency of capitalism. 

But let's look at something simple like a house. Compare the cost of a home today to a cost of a home hundreds of years ago. In the old days, you essentially could just go off and build a home. All you needed was enough manpower, work ethic, and a forest. It was hard work for sure, but it was doable. Most houses nowadays cost at least 300k. Depending on your wage, thats gonna be about 15,000 hours of work. I'm fairly sure that if you told Abe Lincoln that in order to get a home you'd have to sacrifice 5 years of manual labor, plus some for food water clothes etc, he'd tell you that's ridiculous. And it is. Most people essentially become indentured servants to the bank because of it. Also look what's happening now. Giant conglomerates are buying up homes before average Americans can purchase them. Not only is it driving up costs, but more and more the only option to live in a home is to rent it from one of these companies. But that's capitalism. The haves own what you need, and your only option is to do what they say, or don't get the thing they have. But that's entirely "fair" and anyone who questions it is just "lazy" for not wanting to do what they say right? 

What about food? Everyone's gotta work for food right? Well with factory farming that's becoming less of the case. They're making food with maybe 2 or three workers in the facility. What do you think is going to happen if humanity makes the technology to give us every resource we need without labor? They're still gonna charge as much as they possibly can. 

It's kinda dumb having this conversation on your tube lmao. Probably not gonna keep going with this. But that "if I question I'm just lazy" attitude is terrible. You should always question a system, and make sure to look for the ones who are REALLY leaching off the system. They want you mad at your fellow american my friend. Idk just keep an open mind. Have a good one

author: @nathandavis9830
text:
For any libertarians or libertarian-adjacent people browsing around:

There is such a thing that you could call "communal crimes," where every action taken by individuals might be fine in isolation, but collectively the actions create harm. Perhaps the easiest-to-understand example of this is overfishing. Each individual fisher isn't overfishing and might even be fishing a reasonable amount when looked at in isolation, but when combined with every other fisher, overfishing can occur. And harm to communities occurs because of the overfishing. Other examples are things like pollution or discrimination.

Anyway, the point is that the libertarian in this video who's arguing that since no individual "actor" is forcing anyone to work, then coercion isn't occurring...is basically speaking nonsense. Systemic coercion can (and does) occur the same way that overfishing can occur. And capitalists take advantage of that systemic coercion to get workers to accept lower wages than the workers would otherwise be able to get (this is proven by the fact that unions are able to counteract underpaying to a certain degree--unions jobs pay more than non-union jobs in the same sector, on average).

Life is more complicated than just individuals acting in isolation. And if libertarianism is unable to take those complications into account, then it's going to allow a lot of preventable harm to occur. Which makes it a failure of an ideology, in my opinion.

author: @samp9418
text:
Cool debate, but I think you missed the mark when debating whether wage labor is voluntary. I would use the infamous coconut island example to prove that point. 

Coercion occurs by changing the consequences of somebody‚Äôs actions; for example, if I coerce you at gunpoint to give me your wallet, you are still technically choosing to give me your wallet, it‚Äôs just that I have imposed certain consequences on that. 

While it is true that labor is generally necessary under any system, there are new consequences imposed on me as a result for not laboring, namely, getting evicted from my home. This is a consequence imposed by the system and is not from a state of nature. Likewise, the system makes it so I can‚Äôt just go farming or apple picking or hunting because there isn‚Äôt land for that.

When asked for ‚Äúwho‚Äù is doing the coercion, the answer is the police and the owners of the property. 

You could also push back more on the expropriation of the commons, which is another form of coercion and theft. The land in America wasn‚Äôt gotten by homesteading, and even if someone homesteads, why should they still own it if they stop using it? The first acquisition of property is arbitrary and problematic for libertarians. 

I think the argument about China and co. Faking their COVID numbers seems weird but it‚Äôs a point worth engaging with when you get the time. I‚Äôd love to see a video segment on it!

author: @finn.schttlr
text: I also follow your TikTok account and I really love your videos, but one thing I never really understand is why you are so eager to defend China and the former USSR. From my libertarian socialist pov, the key aspects of the socialist economy and society that I want to create is transferring the means of productions into the hands of the working class, which can democratically decide about how to use them, the abolition of the wage system, and thereby the abolition of the unvoluntary theft of surplus value. If you look at China today, none of those aspects are given at all. Sure, China has a mixed economy with a huge sector of state owned enterprises, but to me, state owned does not equal worker owned. Above that, the current Chinese system accepts private property, and if you just look at the state of workers in China and how they are treated, I do not think that this is anything an actual socialist would have as the idea of an ideal society. So in a way, when you are criticizing that most socialists argue that what we see in China today, or what we saw in the USSR back in the days, is not real socialism, what you are indirectly saying is that what we are now seeing in China is socialism how you would want it, right? And I just do not see how anyone could say that. What we see in China today basically has nothing in common with what Marx, or even any other socialist theorist, advocated for. Why do you cling so desperately to the idea that you have to defend China? Because eventhough I totally think that you won this debate because Aleks and Bens ideas are just absolutely mental and illogical, you have to admit that they kinda got you at that part. If you read this I would be more than happy if you could answer me, because I really want to understand what your pov is, but I just can not understand it by myself.

author: @miltongreedman4895
text: As a Mechanical Engineer I find Ben's example (@56:00) about titanium car bumpers offensive. In our studies we all undergo training on software with databases containing all aspects of materials, including things like carbon footprint, price etc. these software tools allow for materials optimisation subject to constraints. It is in fact part of our job to decide which are the best materials for everything we make. There is a whole field called materials science which mechanical engineers can specialise in. To say that you need "organisers" for this is really dumb, since it has never been the job of any "organiser" to select materials. The engineers do that, and have to operate within budgets. They can literally do everything themselves AND better if they didn't work in monopolistic corporations that push to cut corners and program obsolescence etc. overall I have a subjective feeling that in my lifetime products have been getting less durable and there is no excuse for this given that technological progress should be what the name suggests.

author: @khrachvikkhrachvik7049
text:
This idea that Rockefeller's standard oil represents how monopoly is broken up by the free market is the silliest thing I've ever heard.

Rockefeller would literally go into the offices of small start up competitors, open standard oils books, and say "if you do not sell to us now, we will destroy you and then buy what's left".

Then, the "breaking up" broke it into (I think) 4 companies. And where was that ownership all located? The same families our had been before.

The same families who control the super majors today.

This libertarian kid seems just as utopian as any breadtube type. "well, we need to compare the real world to this fantasy in my head".

If things worked how he thought they did, this would be the reality already. But they don't. And at some point, you gotta grow up and look for the flaw within your previous beliefs, understand that what you think would be good doesn't matter, and realize that the state is an objective phenomenon and must be understood on that basis.

It goes through it's own process of development and undevelopment, and it is Marxism that gives us clarity on how this process happens. Simply shutting your eyes to how the real world functions and never bothering to try to see if what you're being told holds up to scrutiny gets no one anywhere.

author: @DumahAtreides
text:
Negative rights don't exist. The only rights that exist are the sum of our collective interest in protecting any rights. You either have the state protecting private property rights against collective interest of the workers or you have the workers taking power over private property rights. If the state is protecting private property rights, the state is effectively anti-democratic in nature. 



Authority will always be a requirement somewhere. The libertarians are falling under the same trap anarchists do. The lack of authority as a collective will always result in imbalance and ultimately involuntary outcomes. The voluntary aspect comes from a functional democracy - the organized arbitration of collective authority on rights.

author: @jackreed1528
text:
It's not voluntary exchange when one party (the owners) control the means of subsistence, the workers are coerced into the exchange.

 Consent cannot being given when under coercion, all humans are under coercion by nature. Until our basic needs are met and secured we can't consent. For example think of the coconut island thought experiment (I'm sure I've heard it somewhere) where you get stranded on an island where there's only coconuts to eat, but some guy owns the coconuts and will only give them to you if you preform oral sex on him. Are you giving consent in this situation? I think you aren't, for you need those coconuts to survive and thus are being coerced. In the same way under our current society it is impossible to consent to a job. Because we do not guarantee the necessities we need to survive under nature's coercion and thus cannot give consent to anyone. This continues to apply no matter how many individual owners of coconuts nor the diversity of tasks available to gain access to the coconuts.

author: @HaburitheGreat
text:
I would have pushed back on the idea that nature isn't an actor. Spend a day outside and say that. If it's hot, you behave in a way, raining, in another. You'll build a house, eventually. Who is forcing you?? Nature is an actor. 

Now go back to the gilded age, you're black, you leave ur employer, settle somewhere, (make a house,) and somebody burns it down and puts a cross in the front yard. That somebody is the state. 

The argument is the ideal version of libertarian capitalism without the state doesn't eliminate violence. Taking away regulations of capital or oversight of power doesn't help people who are persecuted or even DISABLED. 

Libertarianism is just the lazy (white) man's way to become a millionaire. Why not seriously consider the plight of the least of these?

replies.author: @kjronning1
replies.text: 7:00 You don't own your body or your person. It does not follow that a body or person has to have an owner external to you. You do not have an owner. Bodily autonomy is separate from ownership, as ownership would, for example, allow you to transfer that ownership.

replies.author: @kjronning1
replies.text: On another note, you cannot justify private property without the use of force. Per his own argument, the passive role would be to sit there doing nothing. To have private property you have to actively defend it from other people that want to use it (mind you, private property you're not currently using) and you would have to defend it with force. Therefore, you cannot argumentatively and peacfully defend private property.

replies.author: @kjronning1
replies.text: 21:00 desequilibrium, sure sounds good. Except that monopolies have so much economic power that they can lower prices and actually lose money so that no entrepeneurs can succesfully arise. We see this currently with Amazon, Uber, etc.

replies.author: @kjronning1
replies.text: 22:00 sure, nature is a passive actor, but the active actors are the owners of property. These are the people that coerce you by owning the land and not letting you work it by yourself and for yourself, and thus starving to death. This is the crux of why the NAP is violated the instant that you create private property.

replies.author: @kjronning1
replies.text: 27:00 industralization is not a natural thing, and the working conditions in it were not inevitable. Natural fallacy at the worst.

replies.author: @kjronning1
replies.text: 28:00 again, children having to work is not a "thing that has to happen." Rapid industrialisation required it so that capitalists could extract as much profit as possible from the population, but that's a necessity of unregulated capitalism, not industralisation.

replies.author: @kjronning1
replies.text: 35:00 charity is not mutual aid, since charity is inherently hierirchical in its structure. Crazy the amount of hierarchies these "anarchists" seem to approve of.

replies.author: @kjronning1
replies.text: 42:00 peak political blindness is saying "my system is not achievable, but it's better." Politics is not a thought experiment, it's lived every day by thousands of millions of people all around the world. What a privileged life you must lead to not be affected by politics and being able to reduce it to utopian thought experiments.

author: @antediluvianatheist5262
text:
'It's voluntary'
You are hanging from a cliff by a rope. It's my rope.
I tell you that you can freely continue to use my rope, but only if you pay me [way too much]
So you have the FREE CHOICE to pay me what i want, or fall, as i remove MY rope.
Is it voluntary?
It's like these idiots don't understand coercion.

'Entrepreneurs' 
That's nice. How do they break into the market, when the monopoly or big boys dominate the market, and can rub you out by buying you out, or undercutting you till you go bust, then they buy you out?

'Private charity' 
Yeah? What if there's not enough to go around? Then what? What if people don't feel like giving enough to actually do the job?
Do they then die?

replies.author: @gustaveliasson5395
replies.text:
Your grandparents built their business using people who were pushed into the workforce through the expropriation of land from the peasantry. Even if you yourself were the worker who made that rope, you made it using means of production that were ultimately born from expropriation.
So no, it's not your rope.
